questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset severe substernal chest pain. The patient reports associated palpitations but no shortness of breath, cough, or fever. Past medical history includes an appendectomy two years ago. He does not take any medications. His temperature is 37.2°C (98.9 F), pulse is 123/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. The patient appears agitated and diaphoretic. His pupils are mydriatic and nasal mucosa appears atrophic. The cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. ECG shows sinus tachycardia with ST elevations in leads V1-V4 and reciprocal depressions. Which of the following medications is contraindicated in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with severe sudden onset substernal chest pain and ST elevation in leads V1-V4, consistent with acute ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). Clinical findings of mydriasis tachycardia and hypertension in combination with atrophic nasal mucosa suggest cocaine intoxication. Beta-blockers are contraindicated in the treatment of cocaine-induced myocardial infarction, as their use can precipitate unopposed alpha-adrenergic stimulation, worsening coronary vasoconstriction. Other contraindications of beta blockers include:  

  •  Pheochromocytoma due to unopposed alpha agonism  
  •  Concomitant use in patients with calcium channel blockers because of their additive effect on conduction velocity through the AV node leading to the disruption of electrical impulse conduction from the atria to the ventricles. 
  •  Obstructive lung disease (e.g., asthma and COPD) 
  Side effects of beta blockers can be divided into cardiac and noncardiac.  
 
  •  Cardiac: SA node depression (sinus bradycardia), heart block, vasospastic angina (propranolol), and heart failure 
  •  Extracardiac: Fatigue, sedation, dyslipidemia (metoprolol), sleep disturbance, sexual dysfunction, dyspnea, and bronchospasm  
 
Beta blockers can lead to hypoglycemia unawareness. This refers to an individual with diabetes that takes a beta blocker and develops hypoglycemia without typical hypoglycemic symptoms. This occurs since beta-blockers inhibit the effects of epinephrine (e.g., tachycardia, palpitations, tremor, and anxiety).  



Option Analysis

❌ Aspirin:
Incorrect: Aspirin carries antiplatelet effects and mitigates thrombus formation. It should be administered immediately in patients with chest pain and evidence of myocardial infarction.
❌ Nitroglycerin:
Incorrect: Nitroglycerin dilates large coronary arteries and arterioles, leading to increased perfusion. It is beneficial for cocaine-induced coronary artery vasospasm.
❌ Benzodiazepine:
Incorrect: Benzodiazepines reduce anxiety and agitation and improve blood pressure and heart rate. It is often indicated in the management of chest pain associated with sympathomimetic use.  
✅ Propranolol:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Diltiazem:
Incorrect: Like nitroglycerin, diltiazem acts as a vasodilator and is beneficial for cocaine-induced coronary artery vasoconstriction.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man is evaluated in the hospital for low blood pressure several hours after an open cholecystectomy. The patient describes mid-sternal chest pressure and significant shortness of breath. His past medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus, dyslipidemia, hypertension, and daily tobacco use. An outpatient transthoracic echocardiogram performed six months ago was normal. Current medications include amlodipine, clonidine, metformin, and pravastatin. Temperature is 36.5 ºC (97.7 ºF), pulse is 108/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, blood pressure is 81/40 mmHg, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 94% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is ill-appearing. There is no significant jugular venous distention. The chest pressure is not reproducible with palpation. Cardiac sounds are audible, and there are faint bibasilar crackles on lung auscultation. An ECG demonstrates a new left bundle branch block. Bedside transthoracic echocardiogram shows a small pericardial effusion, severe anterior and septal hypokinesis, and a dilated left ventricle with reduced ejection fraction. Laboratory studies are pending. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient who has several risk factors for coronary artery disease (i.e., age, diabetes mellitus, dyslipidemia, hypertension, tobacco use) has developed hypotension and chest pressure in the postoperative period. ECG shows a new left bundle branch block and transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) shows new wall motion abnormalities and a dilated, poorly functioning left ventricle. These findings associated with chest pressure are highly concerning for postoperative myocardial infarction. Thus, left heart catheterization is warranted.

Postoperative hypotension is relatively common. Acute cardiopulmonary issues that cause postoperative hypotension are life-threatening and may include tension pneumothorax, pulmonary embolism, myocardial infarction, and cardiac tamponade. Anaphylaxis can occur during anesthesia induction or postoperatively. Severe blood loss may occur and lead to hemorrhagic shock. Urgent but usually not life-threatening causes of postoperative hypotension include significant intraoperative fluid loss, poor sympathetic tone from neuraxial analgesia, and adrenal crisis in patients with underlying adrenal insufficiency.

Management of postoperative hypotension always begins with an ABCDE assessment. Patients should be given IV fluid resuscitation and may need to be started on vasopressors to stabilize their blood pressure. Laboratory studies should be checked, including a complete blood count and comprehensive metabolic panel.

If a cardiopulmonary cause is suspected, then a chest X-ray is indicated, which may reveal pulmonary edema or a pneumothorax. CT imaging of the chest should be performed if pulmonary embolism is suspected.  Serum troponin levels, electrocardiogram, and transthoracic echocardiogram can diagnose cardiac causes (e.g., myocardial infarction, pericardial tamponade). Treatment is then based on the underlying cause (e.g., chest tube for pneumothorax, epinephrine for anaphylaxis).  

Option Analysis

✅ Left heart catheterization:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Phenylephrine infusion:
Incorrect: While vasopressors may be necessary to augment blood pressure in this patient, phenylephrine is not an appropriate first-line vasopressor in this case. Dobutamine, dopamine, or norepinephrine would be more appropriate for this patient with suspected myocardial infarction if pressors are needed.  
❌ Pericardiocentesis:
Incorrect: This would be appropriate if the patient had evidence of cardiac tamponade (e.g., jugular venous distention, distant heart sounds, right atrial and ventricular collapse on echo). This patient’s new onset chest pressure, ECG findings, new wall motion abnormality, and lack of clinical and echocardiographic signs of tamponade suggest myocardial infarction which should be managed with left heart catheterization.  
❌ Intravenous metoprolol tartrate:
Incorrect: Starting beta-blockers during acute heart failure and prior to stabilization of myocardial infarction can worsen hypotension and cardiac decompensation.  
❌ Intravenous furosemide:
Incorrect: This would be appropriate treatment after diagnosis and treatment with left heart catheterization if the patient had significant volume overload and signs of heart failure. This patient currently is saturating well on room air and only has faint pulmonary crackles. At this point, revascularization of the coronary arteries is most important.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the emergency department to be evaluated for retrosternal chest pain. The pain started four hours ago while playing soccer with his grandchild. The pain radiates to his left arm and jaw and is not associated with breathing or position changes. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Cardiac catheterization is performed via the femoral artery and demonstrates stenosis of the following arteries: 70% left main coronary artery, 90% proximal left anterior descending artery, and 80% right coronary artery. Six hours following catheterization, the patient states that he is experiencing generalized weakness and back pain. Temperature is 37.1℃ (98.8℉), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 96/60 mmHg. Physical examination demonstrates cold and clammy extremities. A 5 cm area of ecchymosis is noted surrounding the femoral puncture site. Palpation and auscultation of catheter access sites are unremarkable. The patient has palpable, thready dorsalis pedis pulses bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of sudden onset back pain, generalized weakness, and hypotension with cold and clammy extremities after cardiac catheterization is consistent with retroperitoneal hemorrhage. This patient’s condition likely occurred secondary to accidental puncture of the posterior wall of the common femoral artery.   

The common femoral artery serves as the continuation of the external iliac artery as it crosses the inguinal ligament and is often used as a site for vascular access. Retroperitoneal bleeding is frequently related to artery puncture above the inguinal ligament, as this portion of the vessel lies directly inferior to the peritoneum. Accidental puncture of the posterior wall of the common femoral artery can cause blood to track along the vascular fascial sheath into the retroperitoneum or rectus sheath.  

Due to the size of the retroperitoneal space, significant hemorrhage can occur before the development of any clinical signs or symptoms. Back pain, hypotension, and a significant drop in hemoglobin after a procedure are signs of a retroperitoneal hemorrhage. Diagnosis is confirmed via computed tomography imaging.  

Option Analysis

❌ Pseudoaneurysm:
Incorrect: A pseudoaneurysm is associated with clinical findings of pain at the access site combined with ecchymosis and subcutaneous hematoma. It is often recognized by the presence of a pulsatile mass with a systolic bruit overlying the catheter insertion site. This patient does not have symptoms or signs on physical examination of a pseudoaneurysm. Pseudoaneurysms do not typically lead to loss of a large volume of blood and hypotension. 
❌ Arteriovenous fistula:
Incorrect: Bleeding from the arterial puncture site may fistulize into the adjacent femoral vein. It may be recognized clinically by the presence of a thrill or continuous bruit. The time of symptom onset ranges from two days to several months after catheterization.
❌ Allergic reaction to iodinated contrast:
Incorrect: An allergic reaction to iodinated contrast typically presents with urticaria, pruritus, facial edema, as well as transient warmth or chills. Allergic reactions usually occur within twenty minutes of exposure. Anaphylaxis from contrast media occurs within minutes of exposure.
✅ Retroperitoneal hemorrhage:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Arterial thrombosis:
Incorrect: Patients with lower extremity arterial thrombosis present with pain or paresthesias in the affected leg, as well as reduced or absent distal pulses.

A 67-year-old man presents to the primary care physician with a several week history of worsening fatigue, blurry vision, and rectal bleeding. Medical history is notable for ulcerative colitis, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. The patient’s last colonoscopy was at age 50. Temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 96/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 122/63 mmHg. BMI is 34 kg/m2. Physical examination demonstrates an obese habitus. The patient’s skin appears pale with noted conjunctival pallor. Cardiopulmonary examination demonstrates a 3/6 holosystolic murmur best at the cardiac apex which was not present at the previous office visit 3 months ago. Retinal examination demonstrates round white spots on the retina surrounded by hemorrhage. Rectal examination is positive for scant blood in the rectal vault. Laboratory values are demonstrated below:  
 
Laboratory value  Result 
Complete Blood Count, Serum 
Hemoglobin  11.5 g/dL 
 Hematocrit  39.5% 
 Leukocyte count  14,100 /mm3 
 Platelet count  155,000/mm3 
Electrolytes, Serum 
                  Sodium                134 mEq/L 
               Potassium                 3.6 mEq/L

              Bicarbonate                 22 mEq/L 
                 Calcium                8.4 mg/dL 
Blood is drawn and sent for culture. Two days later, 3 of 4 blood cultures obtained grow Streptococcus gallolyticus (Streptococcus bovis biotype I). Which of the following studies is most likely to reveal the etiology of this patient’s infection?

choices.text: CT of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
Infective endocarditis due to Streptococcus gallolyticus, also known as Streptococcus bovis biotype I, has a high association with underlying colorectal cancer; patients who have a positive blood culture for this organism should be evaluated via colonoscopy. Given that this patient also has a history of ulcerative colitis, in addition to pallor and a normocytic anemia, he should undergo a colonoscopy to screen for underlying colorectal cancer.  

S. bovis is strongly associated with colorectal cancer; however, not all genospecies are as closely related to the disease. A recent meta-analysis on the association between S. bovis biotypes and colonic adenomas/carcinomas revealed that patients with S. bovis biotype I infection had a strongly increased risk of having colorectal cancer compared to S. bovis biotype II-infected patients. Streptococcus bovis is a common bacteria in the human gastrointestinal tract, and therefore, the main portal of entry for human infection of S. bovis bacteremia is the GI tract. Because of this association, patients with S. bovis biotype I bacteremia should undergo a colonoscopy to look for an underlying malignancy.  

Option Analysis

✅ Colonoscopy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ CT of the abdomen and pelvis :
Incorrect: While a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis may reveal underlying colorectal cancer or other forms of malignancy, it is not the definitive diagnostic test when there is a suspicion for underlying colorectal cancer.   
❌ Upper endoscopy:
Incorrect: While an upper endoscopy may reveal esophageal carcinoma, or metastatic disease, these conditions do not have an association with Streptococcus bovis endocarditis or colorectal cancer. Additionally, this patient does not have any symptoms of esophageal cancer such as hemoptysis or dysphagia, making this test inappropriate.   
❌ CT of the chest:
Incorrect:Streptococcus bovis is a common bacteria in the human gastrointestinal tract, and therefore, further diagnostic tests of the gastrointestinal tract should be performed. Additionally, the infective endocarditis would not be diagnosed with a CT scan.  
❌ Cystoscopy:
Incorrect: The genitourinary tract is commonly colonized by Enterococcal species, and therefore, patients who have recently undergone a cystoscopy (or any other genitourinary procedure) may be at a higher risk of enterococcal endocarditis. However, performing a cystoscopy now is unlikely to reveal the underlying condition that caused this patient’s bacteremia.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with a history of hypertension and bicuspid aortic valve presents to the primary care office with a 7-week history of malaise, chills, and subjective fevers. The patient reports he has otherwise been in his usual state of health and endorses compliance with his home medication regimen. He additionally complains of dyspnea on exertion as well as intermittent chest tightness. The patient has a past surgical history of total hip replacement at 61 as well as a molar tooth extraction two months ago. Temperature is 37.7°C (100.6 °F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 140/62 mmHg. Cardiac examination is notable for an ejection click and a blowing diastolic murmur best heard at the second intercostal space of the right sternal border. Follow-up blood cultures are positive for a Gram-positive alpha-hemolytic bacteria. Which of the following is the best initial test to aid in the diagnosis of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis

questions.solution:
Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) is the best first line imaging modality when the diagnosis of bacterial endocarditis is suspected. Echocardiography is useful for evaluating valvular dysfunction, assessing hemodynamic severity of valvular lesions, assessing underlying ventricular function, and detecting associated abnormalities such as shunts.  

If TTE is negative, or if TTE is positive with significant concern for paravalvular complications requiring surgery, a transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) may be performed. This mode of imaging has the highest sensitivity for detection of valvular vegetation and is superior to TTE for detection of cardiac complications such as abscess, leaflet perforation, and pseudoaneurysm; however, due to its much more invasive nature, it is not first-line in the diagnosis of bacterial endocarditis.  

Option Analysis

❌ Repeat blood cultures:
Incorrect: While surveillance blood cultures are an important component in the diagnosis and treatment for patients with bacterial endocarditis, repeating them is not the best test to help confirm the diagnosis.   
✅ Transthoracic echocardiogram:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Colonoscopy:
Incorrect: Endocarditis due to Streptococcus gallolyticus, also known as Streptococcus bovis, has a high association with underlying colorectal cancer. Patients with positive blood cultures growing this bacteria should undergo screening with a colonoscopy. It is not, however, the best test indicated at this time since confirmatory testing of bacterial endocarditis is first needed.  
❌ CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis:
Incorrect: CT of the chest abdomen and pelvis may be helpful in elucidating embolic phenomena of endocarditis, including splenic or renal abscesses; however, it is not the best first line diagnostic test.   
❌ Cardiac MRI:
Incorrect: Cardiac MRI may be useful for detection of antegrade and retrograde dissemination, paravalvular tissue extension, and subendocardial and vascular endothelial involvement; however, it is not the best initial test for confirmatory testing to diagnose bacterial endocarditis.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to recent onset of chest pain. Initially, he felt chest discomfort that progressed to sharp chest pain, rated as 7/10 in intensity, with radiation to the upper back. He reports that one week ago he recovered from an upper respiratory infection that resolved without treatment. Medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus type 2 and hyperlipidemia. He has been smoking half-a-pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years. Temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is in acute distress due to pain and is sweating profusely. An ECG is performed and is shown below:  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  

Which of the following interventions is the most appropriate for this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Aspirin, nitrates, beta blocker, and oxygen
Nonsteroidal anti inflammatory drugs and colchicine

questions.solution:
This patient, who is presenting with fever and sharp chest radiating to the back following a viral infection, most likely has acute pericarditis. The ECG is showing classic diffuse ST elevation in multiple leads, as indicated by the red arrows.  

Pericarditis refers to inflammation of the pericardium, the fibroelastic sac that surrounds the heart. Causes include infectious (e.g., coxsackie, TB), autoimmune (e.g. SLE), neoplasm, post-myocardial infarction, metabolic (e.g. uremia), certain drugs (e.g. isoniazid), post-trauma, or idiopathic. In developed countries, the majority of cases of acute pericarditis are considered of viral origin, although the exact etiology often remains undetermined.    



Signs and symptoms of acute pericarditis include acute onset of sharp chest pain, fever, and diaphoresis. The chest pain is pleuritic, worse with coughing or lying down, and improves with leaning forward and sitting upright. This position (seated, leaning forward) reduces pressure on the parietal pericardium, alleviating the pain. Exertion does not affect the chest pain, in comparison to anginal pain. The pain often radiates to the trapezius ridge, which is a fairly specific finding of pericarditis. On physical examination, cardiac auscultation may reveal a friction rub. Pericardial friction rub is auscultated over the lower left sternal border and is described as a high-pitched squeaking sound.  

Diagnosis is based on the clinical symptoms and ECG findings showing diffuse ST elevation and/or PR depression in multiple leads. Treatment should be targeted to the underlying etiology, but since most cases in developed countries are idiopathic or due to viral infection, empiric treatment with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and colchicine is often used.  

Option Analysis

❌ Percutaneous coronary intervention:
Incorrect: Percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) is the mainstay therapy for ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) to restore blood flow. It is also used less frequently in other conditions including non ST-elevation MI, unstable angina and stable angina. PCI is a minimally invasive nonsurgical procedure that restores blood flow by balloon or stent. Patients with STEMI will likely describe crushing chest pain that radiates to the neck and jaw. ECG in STEMI will show an elevated ST segment in specific leads, as opposed to the diffusely elevated ST segments seen in this patient’s ECG.   
❌ Aspirin, nitrates, beta blocker, and oxygen:
Incorrect: Aspirin, nitrates, beta-blockers, and oxygen are given to almost every patient with acute coronary syndrome (STEMI or NSTEMI) as well as unstable angina. This patient's presentation and ECG findings are instead consistent with pericarditis. 
❌ Fibrinolytic therapy  :
Incorrect: Fibrinolytic therapy is reserved for patients with ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) in which the onset of symptoms occurred in the last 12 hours but they cannot receive primary percutaneous coronary intervention within 120 minutes of first medical contact. This patient's presentation and ECG findings are instead consistent with pericarditis.  
✅ Nonsteroidal anti inflammatory drugs and colchicine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Pericardiocentesis :
Incorrect: Pericardiocentesis is a procedure used in cardiac tamponade. It involves needle and catheter insertion into the pericardium to remove excess fluid. Electrocardiogram in cardiac tamponade typically shows normal sinus tachycardia and electrical alternans, which is characterized by beat-to-beat changes in the amplitude of the QRS complex. This patient's presentation and ECG findings are consistent with pericarditis. Cardiac tamponade is a possible complication of pericarditis.

questions.text: A 66-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by ambulance for shortness of breath. She reports that over the past 2-3 days she has had worsening shortness of breath with, and now without, exertion. She is currently being treated for metastatic breast cancer with chemotherapy and radiation. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 90/61 mmHg, pulse is 121/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. Cardiopulmonary examination demonstrates jugular venous distention. Point of care ultrasound shows a large pericardial effusion and compression of the right ventricle. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: CT of the chest with contrast

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of metastatic breast cancer presents with shortness of breath, jugular venous distention, and ultrasonography demonstrating evidence of a large pericardial effusion with compression of the right ventricle consistent with pericardial tamponade. Given this patient's associated hemodynamic instability, the best next step in management is pericardiocentesis.

Cardiac tamponade is a life-threatening condition characterized by excessive fluid accumulation in the pericardial sac, which exerts pressure on the heart and decreases the filling of the cardiac chambers, eventually reducing cardiac output. Cardiac tamponade can occur due to effusive-constrictive pericarditis, often as a result of infection, uremia, or malignancy. Patients with cardiac tamponade are typically hemodynamically unstable and may quickly develop cardiovascular collapse and cardiac arrest. They require prompt recognition and treatment with emergent pericardiocentesis to drain the pericardial fluid and restore cardiac output.

Acute management of patients with suspected cardiac tamponade includes an airway, breathing, and circulation assessment. Patients with evidence of hemodynamic instability should have their airway stabilized, IV access obtained, and supplemental oxygen applied as needed.  Patients should have intravenous fluids administered if they are hypotensive, and a bedside ultrasonography should be performed immediately. Additional work-up includes obtaining a twelve-lead ECG, as well as a chest x-ray. Characteristic ultrasonography findings include large pericardial effusion, as well as compression of the right atrium during systole, and RA collapse during diastole. Patients with these findings should undergo immediate percutaneous pericardiocentesis prior to further diagnostic evaluation and management.  

Option Analysis

✅ Pericardiocentesis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Cardiac catheterization:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of pericardial tamponade and should undergo emergent pericardiocentesis. Cardiac catheterization is indicated for patients with suspicion of underlying ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI).  
❌ Emergent dialysis:
Incorrect: Emergent dialysis is often indicated for patients with cardiac tamponade secondary to uremia following pericardiocentesis. Given that this patient has evidence of hemodynamic instability, she should first undergo emergent pericardiocentesis.  
❌ CT of the chest with contrast:
Incorrect: CT of the chest with contrast is indicated for diagnosis of a pulmonary embolism.  While this patient's malignancy history places her at increased risk for thromboembolism, her presentation is more consistent with pericardial tamponade.  
❌ Administration of aspirin:
Incorrect: Aspirin is indicated in the management of acute coronary syndrome. This patient has evidence of pericardial tamponade and hemodynamic instability requiring emergent intervention with pericardiocentesis.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to a syncopal episode at work. The patient works in a warehouse. According to his co-worker, the patient was moving heavy boxes when he suddenly collapsed and fell to the floor, after which he regained consciousness within 20 seconds. The patient was alert and oriented immediately after regaining consciousness. He had no chest pain or palpitations prior to the episode. Over the past year, the patient has had transient episodes of lightheadedness related to exercise. He has a remote history of syncope during a wrestling match in high school that was believed to be caused by orthostatic hypotension. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 68/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 128/74 mmHg while supine and 124/70 mmHg while standing. On examination, the patient has no murmurs and lungs are clear to auscultation. ECG shows normal sinus rhythm with left-axis deviation and inverted T waves in V<sub>2</sub>-V<sub>4</sub>. Complete blood count, serum electrolytes, and cardiac enzymes are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation, including his young age, syncope during exertion, and ECG findings of ventricular hypertrophy (left-axis deviation, inverted T waves in V2-V4), raises concern for hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM).

HCM is characterized by asymmetric left ventricular hypertrophy and can lead to outflow obstruction, arrhythmias, ischemia, and death. Syncope in individuals with HCM can occur due to several mechanisms.

1. Obstruction of left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT). Thickening of the heart muscle around the left ventricle can obstruct the outflow of blood from the left ventricle, especially during exercise or exertion, leading to a sudden drop in blood pressure and syncope.

2. Arrhythmias associated with HCM, including atrial fibrillation and ventricular tachycardia can lead to a rapid decrease in cardiac output and cause syncope.

3. Ischemia: The thickened heart muscle in HCM may require more oxygen, and narrowed coronary arteries, which are often found in HCM patients, can limit oxygen supply to the heart muscle. During increased physical activity, the heart muscles may become ischemic, leading to symptoms like chest pain and syncope.

The physical examination can be normal in HCM, as it is in this patient, or it may reveal a nonspecific fourth heart sound, a systolic murmur, or an LV lift. Patients with left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction might have a sharp, crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur. This murmur usually starts just after the first heart sound (S1) and is most audible at the apex and lower left sternal edge. Various physical examination techniques can alter the level of obstruction, leading to a variation in the loudness of the murmur. Diagnosis is made with echocardiography, which typically demonstrates asymmetric LV hypertrophy primarily affecting the interventricular septum, dynamic LVOT obstruction, LV diastolic dysfunction, and left atrial dilation.  

Option Analysis

❌ Ambulatory ECG monitoring:
Incorrect: Ambulatory ECG monitoring is helpful for diagnosing intermittent arrhythmias and could detect paroxysmal atrial fibrillation or ventricular tachycardia which can lead to syncope. However, this patient’s presentation, history, and ECG findings suggest hypertrophic cardiomyopathy which should be assessed further with an echocardiogram.
❌ Pacemaker placement:
Incorrect: Pacemaker placement is indicated in cases of significant bradyarrhythmias or heart block, where the heart’s natural pacemaker is unable to maintain an adequate heart rate. This patient’s heart rate and EKG pattern are more suggestive of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and there is no evidence of bradyarrhythmia or heart block.  
❌ Coronary angiography:
Incorrect: Coronary angiography is used to evaluate for coronary artery disease, particularly in patients presenting with chest pain or ischemic changes on ECG. This patient's age, lack of chest pain, and ECG findings are more consistent with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.  
✅ Echocardiography:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Oral rehydration and reassurance:
Incorrect: Oral rehydration and reassurance may be appropriate for syncope due to orthostatic hypotension from dehydration or vasovagal episodes, but this patient's recurrent exercise-related symptoms and specific ECG findings point towards hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM), which should be assessed further with an echocardiogram.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of fever, chills and generalized weakness for the past week. The patient has no cough, arthralgias, or diarrhea. Past medical history is noncontributory and he does not take any medications. The patient underwent a tooth extraction 6 weeks ago. Temperature is 39°C (102.2 F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 17/min and blood pressure is 130/76 mm Hg. Physical examination shows non-blanching brown lesions under the nail bed. Examination of the palms and soles are shown in the image below. An early diastolic murmur is heard at the left sternal border. Chest x-ray and ECG are unremarkable. Three sets of blood cultures are obtained and the patient is started on empiric penicillin G. Blood cultures grow viridans streptococci which are found to be relatively resistant to penicillin. Addition of which of the following medications will act synergistically to improve bactericidal activity?
 
Reproduced from Flickr
questions.solution:
This patient presents with multiple clinical features suspicious for infective endocarditis (IE) and blood cultures that grow Viridans streptococci. Penicillin G in combination with gentamicin (aminoglycoside) is the recommended treatment regimen in patients with native-valve endocarditis due to penicillin-resistant streptococcus.

Aminoglycosides should not be used as monotherapy to treat infections caused by gram-positive bacteria due to their limited activity. In combination with cell wall inhibitors, such as penicillin or vancomycin, an aminoglycoside can yield a synergistic bactericidal effect. Cell wall inhibitors induce structural defects in the bacterial cell wall that allow the aminoglycoside to gain entry into the bacteria.
     
 

Option Analysis

❌ Vancomycin :
Incorrect: Vancomycin can be used as monotherapy to treat infective endocarditis in patients with resistance to penicillin. Vancomycin combined with penicillin does not improve bactericidal activity against viridans streptococci. 
✅ Gentamicin :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Chloramphenicol :
Incorrect: Chloramphenicol can be used to treat meningitis caused by Haemophilus influenzae, Neisseria meningitidis, Streptococcus pneumoniae or rickettsial diseases. Use of this medication is limited due to its toxicity profile. It does not act synergistically with β-lactams. 
❌ Linezolid :
Incorrect: Linezolid is a protein synthesis inhibitor used to treat gram-positive bacterial infections (MRSA) and vancomycin resistant organisms. It can be used in the treatment of endocarditis secondary to MRSA or VRE, but it is not effective against penicillin resistant streptococci.  
❌ Daptomycin :
Incorrect: Daptomycin is a lipopeptide that can be used in the treatment of endocarditis secondary to MRSA or VRE, but it is not effective against penicillin-resistant streptococci.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of fever, hemoptysis, and shortness of breath. Past medical history is significant for a 20-pack smoking history and intravenous drug use. Temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), blood pressure is 98/69 mm Hg, pulse is 112/min, and respiratory rate is 28/min, and oxygen saturation is 90% on room air.  Physical examination is significant for scattered non-painful erythematous macules over the palms and soles, and a new grade 4/6 holosystolic murmur over the lower left sternal border radiating to the right lower sternal border. Lung auscultation is significant for decreased breath sounds at the lung base bilaterally. Laboratory evaluation shows a white blood cell count of 18,000/mm3 and a C-reactive protein of 50 mg/L. ECG shows sinus tachycardia. Chest CT scan with IV contrast is shown below. Blood cultures are sent and IV fluids are initiated with adequate blood pressure response. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
 

Picture taken from openi

choices.text: Administer IV vancomycin and order a transesophageal echocardiogram
Administer IV vancomycin and consult cardiothoracic surgery
Discharge the patient on oral cephalexin
Order a transesophageal echocardiogram and wait for blood culture results before starting antibiotics

questions.solution:
This patient, with a history of injection IV drug use, presents to the emergency department for evaluation of fever, Janeway lesions (scattered non-painful erythematous macules on the palms and soles), and a new-onset holosystolic murmur heard at the left lower sternal border radiating to the right lower sternal border (consistent with murmur of tricuspid regurgitation), suggestive of right-sided infective endocarditis. The presence of dyspnea, hemoptysis, tachycardia, tachypnea, and decreased breath sounds at the right lung base, and the CT scan findings of multiple peripheral alveolar infiltrates indicate septic pulmonary emboli which can be a complication of right-sided infective endocarditis. The most appropriate treatment once blood cultures are obtained is to start empiric antibiotics with vancomycin and order a transesophageal echocardiogram.

Acute management of an adult with infective endocarditis involves obtaining blood cultures, followed by initiation of empiric broad-spectrum antibiotics (to be tailored when blood culture results return). If clinical suspicion for IE is high, then a TEE can be ordered next. Transthoracic echocardiogram may be performed first in certain circumstances. The choice of antibiotic should be based on the most likely pathogens. For most patients, empiric therapy should cover methicillin-susceptible and resistant staphylococci, streptococci, and enterococci. Vancomycin is the appropriate initial therapy for most patients. A transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) should be performed, as it is more sensitive than transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) in detecting vegetation and abscesses. However, TTE may be the initial imaging in some circumstances. Early (before completion of antibiotic course) surgical management may also be indicated for certain conditions including heart failure secondary to valvular destruction, persistent bacteremia, large vegetations/persistent septic emboli, difficult-to-eradicate organisms like fungi or multidrug-resistant bacteria, or extension of infection causing abscess, fistula, or heart block.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Administer IV vancomycin and order a transesophageal echocardiogram:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Administer IV vancomycin and consult cardiothoracic surgery:
Incorrect: While cardiothoracic surgery may need to be consulted based on the finding of the TEE, it is crucial to first perform a transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) to confirm the diagnosis and evaluate for complications of infective endocarditis.  
❌ Administer IV vancomycin and heparin:
Incorrect: Although IV antibiotics are indicated, heparin is not. This patient’s findings point towards septic pulmonary emboli, a common complication of right-sided infective endocarditis.  
❌ Discharge the patient on oral cephalexin:
Incorrect: Infective endocarditis is a potentially life-threatening infection that requires hospitalization and intravenous antibiotics. Oral antibiotics are insufficient for managing this condition.  
❌ Order a transesophageal echocardiogram and wait for blood culture results before starting antibiotics:
Incorrect: Waiting for blood culture results before initiating antibiotic therapy may be appropriate for some stable patients without an acute presentation, but would not be appropriate for this patient.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man without significant past medical history presents to the emergency department for evaluation of fatigue, night sweats, and fever for the past week.He has not had a cough, chest pain, or dysuria. Social history is significant for intravenous drug use for the past year. Temperature is 39.2°C (102.6°F), blood pressure is 115/75 mm Hg, pulse is 96/min, and respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. On examination, the patient appears lethargic. Cardiac examination reveals a holosystolic murmur heard at the lower left sternal border that radiates to the right lower sternal border. Laboratory evaluation reveals a hemoglobin of 10.4 g/dL, WBC count of 16,400/mm<sup>3</sup>, and CRP of 25 mg/L. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be found on the physical examination?

choices.text: Tender purplish nodules on the fingertips
Rhonchi over the left lower lung base

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of intravenous drug use presents with fever, night sweats, and a new holosystolic murmur at the lower left sternal border. This clinical presentation is suggestive of infective endocarditis (IE). The presence of Osler nodes is a classic finding in patients with infective endocarditis. Osler nodes are small, tender, purple-pink nodules with a pale center typically found on the distal fingers and toes. They are caused by small-immune complex-mediated vasculitis.

Infective endocarditis (IE) refers to inflammation of the heart's endocardium secondary to infection. Pathogens can adhere to the intracardiac surfaces, leading to the formation of vegetation on heart valves, as well as on the septa, mural endocardium, or implanted electronic devices.

Certain populations are at an increased risk for IE including patients with underlying structural heart disease, patients with prosthetic heart valves, congenital heart disease, or a history of previous IE. Patients who inject drugs are also at high risk due to repeated injection of nonsterile substances. Other risk factors include immunosuppression, the presence of intracardiac devices, and invasive dental/surgical procedures.

The clinical presentation of IE can be varied and is often nonspecific. Patients may present with fever, fatigue, night sweats, weight loss, and other systemic symptoms, which may be persistent or intermittent. A more specific sign of IE is auscultation of a new or changed cardiac murmur. In some cases, IE can result in embolic phenomena, causing symptoms related to stroke, pulmonary embolism, or infarction in other organs. Physical examination may reveal Osler nodes (painful subcutaneous nodules on the fingers and toes), Janeway lesions (hemorrhagic non-painful erythematous macules on the palms and soles), and splinter hemorrhages under the nails. These signs are not always present, and their absence does not rule out the diagnosis. A high degree of clinical suspicion is needed, and definitive diagnosis typically requires an echocardiographic showing vegetation with positive blood cultures.  

Option Analysis

✅ Tender purplish nodules on the fingertips:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Petechiae over the hard palate:
Incorrect: Petechiae can be seen on the conjunctiva and skin in infective endocarditis due to septicemia and disseminated intravascular coagulation. They are not usually found on the hard palate. This finding is most often associated with streptococcal pharyngitis.  
❌ Costovertebral angle tenderness:
Incorrect: This finding is indicative of pyelonephritis. The absence of dysuria and the presence of a new-onset right-sided heart murmur in a patient with a history of intravenous drug use is suggestive of infective endocarditis.  
❌ Rhonchi over the left lower lung base:
Incorrect: This finding is typically seen in patients with lobar pneumonia. The presence of a new-onset murmur in a patient with a history of intravenous drug use is suggestive of infective endocarditis.  
❌ Tender cervical lymphadenopathy:
Incorrect: Although cervical lymphadenopathy is often seen with systemic infections, it is not specific for infective endocarditis. It is more often associated with systemic viral infections such as EBV and HIV, and with localized infections or inflammation in the head and neck including strep pharyngitis.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 2-week history of fever, fatigue, and an erythematous rash over the palms and soles. Past medical history is significant for mitral valve prolapse. The patient has not traveled recently. She is sexually active and uses condoms consistently. Temperature is 38.8°C (101.8°F), blood pressure is 125/78 mm Hg, pulse is 88/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. On physical examination, the patient has several small erythematous non-tender macules over the palmar surface over the hands and on the plantar surface of the feet, and several reddish-brown lesions under the nail beds. Cardiac auscultation is significant for 4/6 late systolic murmur with mid systolic click best heard over the apex, which is a change from prior murmur 2/6. Blood cultures are drawn and a transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) is performed which does not show vegetation. Which of the following is the best next step in the evaluation?

choices.text: Await blood culture results before further evaluation
Obtain a chest CT scan with IV contrast

questions.solution:
This patient presents with a 2-week history of fever, fatigue, and a rash on the palms and soles. The physical examination reveals Janeway lesions and splinter hemorrhages, which are indicative of infective endocarditis (IE) and a change in the murmur related to mitral valve prolapse. Although the transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) did not reveal vegetation, suspicion for IE should remain high and a TEE should be ordered. TTE has a lower sensitivity than transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) for diagnosing IE.

The diagnostic workup for infective endocarditis (IE) involves a combination of clinical, microbiological, and imaging evaluations. The Modified Duke criteria can then be used to determine the likelihood of endocarditis. There are two major criteria and five minor criteria in the Modified Duke Criteria.
 

The major criteria in the Modified Duke Criteria include positive blood cultures with organisms that typically cause IE, such as Staphylococci, Streptococci, HACEK group organisms, and Coxiella burnetti, and evidence of endocardial involvement on echocardiography such as vegetation, abscess, or dehiscence of the prosthetic valve(s). TTE is typically the initial imaging modality of choice. However, in certain scenarios like infection of a prosthetic valve, paravalvular abscess, or a high clinical suspicion of IE, a TEE may be favored due to its superior sensitivity.

The minor criteria in the Modified Duke Criteria include predisposing heart conditions, intravenous drug use, and fever >38.0°C. Additional minor criteria include vascular phenomena such as mycotic aneurysm, intracranial or conjunctival hemorrhages, major arterial emboli, septic infarcts, and Janeway lesions; immunological phenomena such as Roth spots, Osler nodes, glomerulonephritis, or positive rheumatoid; and microbiological evidence that does not meet major criteria.

A diagnosis of IE is established if the patient has 2 major criteria, 1 major and 3 minor criteria, or 5 minor criteria. If the Modified Duke Criteria are not met, alternative diagnoses should be considered.  

Option Analysis

✅ Obtain a transesophageal echocardiogram:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Await blood culture results before further evaluation:
Incorrect: Given the strong clinical suspicion for IE in this patient with a history of mitral valve prolapse and a change in the nature of her murmur, transesophageal echocardiography should be ordered now and not when blood culture results return.  
❌ Obtain a chest CT scan with IV contrast:
Incorrect: A chest CT scan can identify complications or an alternative diagnosis in suspected infective endocarditis, but it does not visualize heart structures as precisely as a TEE, which is indicated in this case.  
❌ Obtain Rickettsia serology:
Incorrect: Rickettsia serology would be appropriate to order for a patient with suspected tick-borne disease like Rocky Mountain spotted fever. Although patients with Rocky Mountain spotted fever present with fever, and a rash that involves the palms and soles, this patient has additional clinical findings that make infective endocarditis more likely.  
❌ Obtain rapid plasma reagin test:
Incorrect: A rapid plasma reagin test is used to screen for syphilis. Secondary syphilis may present with a rash that involves the palms and soles; however, the presence of fever, splinter hemorrhages, and a changed murmur in a patient with a history of mitral valve prolapse, along with the absence of history of signs and symptoms suggestive of primary syphilis makes the diagnosis of infective endocarditis more likely.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 1-week history of fever, fatigue, and night sweats. He has not had a sore throat, cough, diarrhea, or weight loss. The patient has a history of intravenous drug use and admits to sharing needles. Temperature is 39.3°C (102.7°F), blood pressure is 107/71 mm Hg, pulse is 110/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. Physical examination reveals a grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur best heard at the lower left sternal border that radiates to the right lower sternal border. Reddish brown lesions are noted under the nail beds. Laboratory evaluation is significant for leukocytosis and an elevated CRP. ECG shows sinus tachycardia. Blood cultures are drawn and results are pending. A transesophageal echocardiogram shows vegetation on the tricuspid valve. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Admit to the hospital and administer IV vancomycin
Admit to the hospital and administer IV nafcillin
Refer for emergent valve replacement surgery
Discharge home on oral ciprofloxacin and rifampin
Admit to the hospital and administer IV amphotericin B

questions.solution:
This patient, with a history of intravenous drug use, presents with fever, splinter hemorrhages, and a holosystolic murmur best heard at the lower left sternal border radiating to the right lower sternal border (consistent with tricuspid regurgitation) along with findings of leukocytosis and an elevated CRP most likely has right-sided infective endocarditis (IE). The diagnosis is confirmed by the detection of vegetation on the tricuspid valve via transesophageal echocardiography (TEE). Empiric broad-spectrum antibiotics should be initiated and should cover methicillin-susceptible staphylococci, MRSA, Streptococci, and Enterococci. The patient should be admitted to the hospital and started on IV vancomycin.

The choice of empirical antibiotics for IE should be based on the suspected causative organism, which is typically dependent on patient risk factors. Patients who inject drugs are often infected with S. aureus (including MRSA), making vancomycin an appropriate antibiotic choice. Once culture and sensitivity results are available, antibiotics can be tailored to target the specific causative organism. Typical treatment duration is 4-6 months. Early surgical management (before completion of the antibiotic course) may be indicated for certain conditions such as heart failure secondary to valvular destruction, persistent bacteremia despite appropriate antibiotic therapy, large vegetations/persistent septic emboli, a difficult-to-eradicate organism such as fungi or multi-drug resistant bacteria, and extension of infection as evidenced by the presence of an abscess, fistula, or heart block.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Admit to the hospital and administer IV vancomycin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Admit to the hospital and administer IV nafcillin:
Incorrect: Nafcillin, a penicillinase-resistant penicillin, is used to treat methicillin-sensitive staphylococcus aureus. While staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of infective endocarditis in patients who inject IV drugs, empiric therapy should cover MRSA in these patients.  
❌ Refer for emergent valve replacement surgery:
Incorrect: Surgical valve replacement is necessary only in specific cases of infective endocarditis, such as heart failure secondary to valvular destruction, persistent bacteremia despite appropriate antibiotic therapy, large vegetations/persistent septic emboli, difficult-to-eradicate organisms, or extension of infection as evidenced by the presence of an abscess, fistula, or heart block.  
❌ Discharge home on oral ciprofloxacin and rifampin:
Incorrect: Oral antibiotics and discharge are not appropriate. Patients diagnosed with infective endocarditis should be admitted to the hospital for intravenous antibiotics and monitoring.  
❌ Admit to the hospital and administer IV amphotericin B:
Incorrect: Amphotericin B is an antifungal medication that is not used as part of the initial empiric treatment of infective endocarditis. This patient should have empiric antibiotics that cover for the most likely organisms, including MRSA in this case.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man experiences a ST-segment myocardial infarction and is admitted for coronary angiography with stent placement in the left anterior descending artery. On day four of hospitalization, he has sudden sharp chest pain that radiates to his neck and shoulders. The pain is exacerbated by coughing and deep breathing. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a restless man whose symptoms improve when sitting forward from a supine position. There is a loud rubbing sound upon cardiac auscultation when he leans forward. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. An ECG is shown below. The patient is treated with an antiplatelet drug. Which of the following is a common adverse effect of the anti-platelet medication administered in this patient?


Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient with sharp and pleuritic chest pain on the 4th day of hospitalization following an acute ST-elevation myocardial infarction, in combination with ECG findings of diffuse ST-elevation, is suggestive of peri-infarction pericarditis. It is usually managed with aspirin, which risks developing gastric ulcers.

Aspirin is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) with an antiplatelet effect. It irreversibly inhibits the activity of cyclooxygenase enzymes (COX-1 and COX-2) via acetylation, thereby preventing the formation of thromboxane A2, which usually helps in platelet adhesion. It is used in several clinical situations to prevent clots from worsening or provide anti-inflammatory effects:
 
  • A dose of 325 mg is used as a loading dose to treat acute strokes and myocardial infarction. A dose of 81 mg tablets is used as the maintenance therapy 
  • A dose of 650 mg - 1 g every 8 hours is indicated for the treatment of pericarditis, followed by gradual taper after resolution of symptoms. 
Common adverse effects of its use include increased risk of bleeding and gastric ulcers.  

Option Analysis

✅ Gastric ulcers:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Neutropenia:
Incorrect: Neutropenia is a rare but serious adverse effect of the ADP receptor inhibitor, ticlopidine. It prevents platelet aggregation by irreversibly blocking ADP (P2Y12) receptor and inhibiting the expression of glycoproteins IIb/IIIa on the platelet surface. Although it is indicated in managing acute coronary syndrome and coronary stenting, this patient’s symptoms indicate post-MI pericarditis, usually treated with aspirin.  
❌ Osteoporosis:
Incorrect: Osteoporosis is a common adverse effect of heparin therapy. An anticoagulant (not antiplatelet) activates antithrombin in the coagulation pathway, which decreases the action of factor IIa (thrombin) and factor Xa. Although heparin is indicated in patients with coronary stent placement, it cannot alleviate the symptoms of pericarditis.  
❌ Skin necrosis:
Incorrect: Skin and tissue necrosis are serious adverse effects of warfarin therapy and is thought to result from small vessel micro thrombosis. Warfarin is an anticoagulant (not antiplatelet), usually administered in patients requiring chronic anticoagulation (e.g., venous thromboembolism prophylaxis, and stroke prevention in atrial fibrillation). It is not indicated in the treatment of pericarditis.  
❌ Hypotension:
Incorrect: Hypotension is a common adverse effect of phosphodiesterase inhibitors (e.g. cilostazol), which inhibits the breakdown of cyclic guanosine monophosphate in the vascular smooth muscle cells, preventing vasoconstriction. They are usually used to treat peripheral artery disease and coronary artery disease and can be combined with aspirin for secondary prevention of ischemic stroke. They are, however, not indicated in the treatment of acute pericarditis.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man presents to the emergency department with gradually worsening mild chest discomfort, palpitations, and shortness of breath that started 2 days ago. He notes mild fatigue and has had a low-grade fever and cough that began 5 days ago. He has no significant past medical history and does not smoke tobacco or use alcohol or other recreational substances. Temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), blood pressure is 115/70 mmHg, heart rate is 92 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 14 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Cardiac examination reveals a soft S3 gallop, but no murmurs or pericardial rub. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally, and there is no jugular venous distention or peripheral edema. Laboratory results are shown below. An ECG shows nonspecific ST-segment changes and T-wave inversions in the lateral leads. Chest X-ray is unremarkable. Which of the following is most likely to be seen on transthoracic echocardiogram? 

 Laboratory value     Result    
 Cardiac troponins     1.5 ng/mL (normal <0.04)   
 Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)     77 mm/hr (normal <20 mm/hr)   
 C-reactive protein (CRP)     35 mg/L (normal <10 mg/L)

choices.text: Global hypokinesis with a mildly reduced ejection fraction
Apical ballooning with preserved basal function

questions.solution:
In patients with myocarditis, a transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) can reveal global hypokinesis (reduced movement of the myocardium) or regional hypokinesis and reduced ejection fraction (typically between 40-50%). This finding reflects inflammation and injury to the myocardium caused by the underlying myocarditis. In patients like this one with mild myocarditis transthoracic echocardiogram may reveal global hypokinesis and mildly reduced ejection fraction.        

The diagnostic evaluation for suspected myocarditis involves the combination of clinical history and physical examination, laboratory testing, cardiac imaging, and potentially endomyocardial biopsy. Initial tests include ECG, which may show nonspecific ST-segment changes, and blood tests including cardiac troponin and inflammatory markers (e.g., CRP, ESR). Troponins and inflammatory markers are often elevated.       

Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) can usually reveal regional or global hypokinesis and reduced ejection fraction. For patients with mild myocarditis, these changes are typically subtle, while fulminant myocarditis presents with heart failure, marked reduction in ejection fraction and cardiac dysfunction, and signs of cardiogenic shock. Cardiac MRI may also be used to aid in making a diagnosis. Invasive testing with endomyocardial biopsy may be needed to confirm the diagnosis and assess severity.    

Option Analysis

✅ Global hypokinesis with a mildly reduced ejection fraction:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Apical ballooning with preserved basal function:
Incorrect: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy, also known as "broken heart syndrome," is characterized by apical ballooning with normal contraction of the basal segments of the heart. This condition is typically triggered by intense emotional or physical stress and may mimic acute coronary syndrome, with regional wall motion abnormalities. Global hypokinesis of myocarditis with a mildly reduced ejection fraction is more suggestive of myocarditis. 
❌ Concentric left ventricular hypertrophy:
Incorrect: Concentric left ventricular hypertrophy is typically associated with chronic conditions like hypertension or aortic stenosis. Viral Myocarditis involves inflammation of the myocardium, that can lead to global hypokinesis and decreased ejection fraction. 
❌ Large pericardial effusion with tamponade:
Incorrect: A large pericardial effusion with tamponade is more often associated with pericarditis or malignancy. It can lead to life-threatening hemodynamic compromise (e.g., severe hypotension). This patient has more mild symptoms and a recent upper respiratory illness suggestive of myocarditis which can be associated with global hypokinesis and decreased ejection fraction. 
❌ Left ventricular outflow tract obstruction:
Incorrect: This finding is characteristic of hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM), where abnormal septal thickening causes obstruction of blood flow from the left ventricle. Patients can experience exertional chest pain, syncope, or sudden cardiac death. This patient's presentation and findings are more consistent with Myocarditis, which can lead to global hypokinesis and. Decreased ejection fraction.

A 60-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of weight loss, fatigue, and new onset shortness of breath. The patient has lost thirty pounds over the past three months. He states that he has been experiencing chills and a chronic cough. He has no significant past medical history. He smokes 1 pack of cigarettes daily and recently immigrated from Guatemala. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 92/71 mmHg, pulse is 108/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. The patient appears fatigued, short of breath, and cachectic. Physical examination reveals jugular venous distention and muffled heart sounds. A large pericardial effusion and tamponade physiology is identified on bedside ultrasonography, and an emergent pericardiocentesis is performed. The results of the fluid analysis are shown below. Based on these findings, which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?  

Laboratory value

Squamous cells with increased nuclear/cytoplasmic ratio

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of weight loss, fatigue, shortness of breath and is found to have a large pericardial effusion and cardiac tamponade. Based on the results of the pericardial fluid analysis, he has a malignant pericardial effusion.

Cardiac tamponade can occur due to bleeding, which is known as hemopericardium and typically occurs as result of chest trauma, aortic dissection, left ventricular free wall rupture, or iatrogenically as a result of medical interventions. Cardiac tamponade can also occur due to effusive-constrictive pericarditis, often as a result of infection, uremia, or malignancy. Patients with this type of pericardial effusion will have variable characteristics based on the underlying cause. Fluid from pericardiocentesis should be analyzed to help identify the underlying cause of the pericardial effusion. Analysis may include biochemical testing, cytology, gram stain and culture, and immunologic testing. Patients with an infectious etiology will often have fluid that appears cloudy, or purulent with elevated leukocytes. Patients with uremic pericardial effusions tend to have elevated monocytes, and those with malignancy will have malignant cells in the fluid.  

Option Analysis

✅ Malignancy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Uremia:
Incorrect: Patients with end-stage renal disease are susceptible to uremic pericarditis and pericardial effusions. Fluid analysis would typically demonstrate mononuclear cells. This patient’s fluid analysis is suggestive of a malignant etiology.  
❌ Tuberculosis:
Incorrect: Tuberculosis is one of many organisms that can be an infectious cause of pericardial effusions. Patients will often have a history of antecedent infection and pericardial fluid that appears cloudy with increased white blood cells. This patient’s fluid analysis is suggestive of malignancy.  
❌ Coxsackievirus:
Incorrect: Coxsackievirus is one of many viruses that can result in pericarditis and subsequent pericardial effusion. Patients will often have a history of antecedent infection and pericardial fluid that appears cloudy with increased white blood cells. This patient’s fluid analysis is suggestive of malignancy.
❌ Ventricular free wall rupture:
Incorrect: Ventricular free wall rupture would result in hemopericardium and a bloody pericardial effusion. This patient’s fluid analysis is suggestive of malignancy

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department due to shortness of breath. Her symptoms began four hours ago and have progressively worsened. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and right breast adenocarcinoma status-post unilateral mastectomy, which was performed three-months ago. The patient is currently on propranolol, acetaminophen, ondansetron, and chemotherapeutic agents. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 83/min, and blood pressure is 146/82 mmHg. Physical examination reveals diminished breath sounds in the lower lungs. A PA chest x-ray is ordered and reveals the findings below. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the medication most likely responsible for her current symptoms?
 

Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient has shortness of breath in the setting of chemotherapeutic treatment and imaging findings revealing pulmonary edema and cardiomegaly. She most likely has dilated cardiomyopathy secondary to anthracycline use.

Anthracyclines (e.g., doxorubicin, daunorubicin) are a class of antitumor antibiotics used in the treatment of solid tumors (e.g., breath thyroid, lung) as well as leukemias and lymphomas. The medications work via three mechanisms of action: 1) insertion (intercalation) between DNA base pairs to impair RNA synthesis, 2) inhibition of the enzyme topoisomerase II, and 3) generation of free oxygen radicals that damage DNA.

An important side effect is cardiotoxicity secondary to the buildup of free radicals. It often manifests as dilated cardiomyopathy. Since the abnormally dilated heart is no longer effective in pumping blood into the systemic circulation, fluids may accumulate in the lungs and cause pulmonary edema.

Additional side effects of anthracyclines include myelosuppression, impaired wound healing (by decreasing cellular proliferation and regeneration), gastrointestinal distress, and alopecia.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Inhibition of topoisomerase I  :
Incorrect: Topotecan causes DNA damage by inhibiting the enzyme topoisomerase I. Common toxicities of topotecan include myelosuppression and diarrhea. However, it does not typically cause dilated cardiomyopathy.  
❌ Disruption of microtubules assembly:
Incorrect: Vinca alkaloids (e.g., Vincristine, Vinblastine) inhibit tubulin polymerization, thus inhibiting microtubules assembly. These drugs may cause peripheral neuropathy, constipation, and bone marrow suppression. However, they would not typically cause dilated cardiomyopathy.  
✅ Insertion between DNA base pairs:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Inhibition of thymidylate synthase:
Incorrect: 6-mercaptopurine is a purine antimetabolite that inhibits the enzyme thymidylate synthase. The medication is associated with myelosuppression, photosensitivity, and hand-foot syndrome (desquamation of the hands and feet). However, it would not typically cause dilated cardiomyopathy.  
❌ Inhibition of dihydrofolate reductase:
Incorrect: Methotrexate inhibits the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase. As a result, cells are unable to produce tetrahydrofolate, which is required for DNA synthesis. Side effects include myelosuppression, hepatotoxicity, and pulmonary fibrosis. However, it would not typically cause dilated cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents to his oncologist for cough and shortness of breath. His symptoms started three months ago and have progressively worsened. The patient reports feeling short of breath when he lies down and frequently needs to “sit up to get some air.” Past medical history is significant for non-Hodgkin lymphoma, which was diagnosed earlier in the year. The patient is currently undergoing systemic chemotherapy with an agent that intercalates with DNA, inhibits the topoisomerase enzyme, and generates free oxygen radicals. In the office, his temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 128/74 mmHg. Physical examination reveals bibasilar crackles on lung auscultation. In addition, pitting edema is noted in the bilateral lower extremities. Which of the following interventions could have prevented this patient’s current symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient endorses dyspnea, orthopnea, and cough in the setting of chemotherapeutic treatment for non-Hodgkin lymphoma. He likely has cardiotoxicity secondary to anthracycline use. This side effect could have been prevented by administering dexrazoxane.

Anthracyclines (e.g., doxorubicin, daunorubicin) are a class of antitumor antibiotics used in the treatment of solid tumors (e.g., breath thyroid, lung) as well as leukemias and lymphomas. The medications work via three mechanisms of action: 1) insertion (intercalation) between DNA base pairs to impair RNA synthesis, 2) inhibition of the enzyme topoisomerase II, and 3) generation of free oxygen radicals that damage DNA.

An important side effect of anthracyclines is cardiotoxicity secondary to the buildup of free radicals. It often manifests as dilated cardiomyopathy. Since the abnormally dilated heart is no longer effective in pumping blood into the systemic circulation, fluids may accumulate in the lungs (causing pulmonary edema) and venous circulation (causing lower extremity swelling).

Dexrazoxane is used to prevent anthracycline-associated cardiotoxicity. Dexrazoxane is an iron chelator that binds to free and bound iron. It reduces the formation of anthracycline-iron complexes and the subsequent generation of free oxygen radicals, which damage cardiomyocytes.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Mesna:
Incorrect: Mesna is used along with aggressive hydration to prevent hemorrhagic cystitis in patients taking cyclophosphamide. Hemorrhagic cystitis presents with hematuria, dysuria, and suprapubic pain. It is not effective in reducing the cardiotoxic effects of anthracycline agents.  
❌ Folinic acid:
Incorrect: Patients taking methotrexate may develop bone marrow suppression as well as dermatologic and gastrointestinal side effects (e.g., mucositis). These side effects can be potentially reversed by administering folinic acid (leucovorin). This process is termed leucovorin rescue and is not effective in reducing the cardiotoxic effects of anthracycline agents.  
❌ Ondansetron:
Incorrect: Ondansetron is used for treating chemotherapy-associated nausea and vomiting. It blocks  serotonin 5-HT3 receptors. However, it would not prevent pulmonary edema secondary to dilated cardiomyopathy in patients on anthracycline therapy.  
❌ Amifostine:
Incorrect: Amifostine is used to reduce the nephrotoxic effects of platinum-containing chemotherapeutic agents by acting as a free radical scavenger. It is not effective in reducing the cardiotoxic effects of anthracycline agents.  
✅ Dexrazoxane:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

A 39-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic with mild chest discomfort, palpitations, and fatigue for one week. He describes the chest pain as a non-radiating dull ache in the middle of his chest, it is not associated with physical activity or position. He first felt chest discomfort and then, over the week, developed palpitations and fatigue. He has no significant past medical history and takes no medication. Vital signs are within normal limits. He appears comfortable and is in no acute distress. Cardiovascular exam is unremarkable. Lung exam is significant for mild rales at the bases bilaterally. He has 1+ pitting edema of the lower extremities bilaterally. Laboratory results are shown below. An electrocardiogram (ECG) shows nonspecific ST-segment changes and T-wave inversions in the lateral leads. A chest X-ray is normal. Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) reveals mild global hypokinesis with a preserved ejection fraction of 48%. Which of the following most likely preceded this patient's current presentation?

 Laboratory value     Result    
 Cardiac troponins     0.2 ng/mL   
 Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)     45 mm/hr   
 C-reactive protein (CRP)     25 mg/L
questions.solution:
The patient presents with chest discomfort, palpitations, and fatigue that has worsened over one week. Echocardiogram shows global hypokinesis and blood work shows elevated inflammatory markers. This clinical presentation is most consistent with mild viral myocarditis. Viral myocarditis is commonly preceded by a viral illness, that may be an upper respiratory illness, and patients may have exhibited flu-like symptoms (i.e., fever, sore throat, and body aches). These symptoms are often subtle and can resolve before cardiac symptoms become apparent. The viral infection triggers an immune-mediated inflammatory response that affects the myocardium, leading to myocarditis.        

Patients with myocarditis often present with nonspecific symptoms such as chest discomfort, palpitations, shortness of breath, and fatigue. The presentation can vary from mild to severe with cardiogenic shock. On physical examination, findings may include tachycardia and a soft S3 gallop. Clear lung fields, and the absence of peripheral edema may be seen in mild cases. In severe cases, there may be signs of heart failure, such as jugular venous distension (JVD), significant pulmonary rales and lower extremity edema. Patients may develop cardiogenic shock. Inflammatory markers will be elevated in inflammatory cases and troponins may be elevated. Diagnostic findings typically show nonspecific ECG changes like ST-segment abnormalities that may include ST depressions and/or T-wave inversions. Echocardiography may reveal varying degrees of global hypokinesis or regional wall motion abnormalities and reduced ejection fraction.   

Option Analysis

✅ Upper respiratory infection :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Chest trauma:
Incorrect: Chest trauma can cause direct injury to the heart, via myocardial contusion or coronary artery dissection. Cardiac injury usually presents acutely and is not associated with a gradual onset of chest discomfort, shortness of breath and palpitations.  
❌ Dehydration after running a marathon:
Incorrect: Dehydration and electrolyte imbalances can lead to arrhythmias, but they are not typically associated with viral myocarditis.  
❌ Recent emotional stressor:
Incorrect: Emotional stress can lead to acute chest pain from stress cardiomyopathy (Takotsubo); however, Takotsubo is not typically associated with elevated inflammatory markers. This patient’s gradual onset of chest discomfort palpitations and findings of global hypokinesis and elevated inflammatory markers over one week would most likely be due to myocarditis associated with a recent upper respiratory illness.  
❌ Recent initiation of statin therapy:
Incorrect: Statins are occasionally associated with drug-induced myopathy, but they do not typically cause myocarditis. This patient’s gradual onset of chest discomfort and palpitations and fatigue over one week and findings of global hypokinesis and elevated inflammatory markers suggest myocarditis associated with a recent upper respiratory illness.
